column1: Berlin Tegel "Otto Lilienthal" Airport (German: Flughafen Berlin-Tegel „Otto Lilienthal“) (IATA: TXL
column2: ICAO: EDDT) is the main international airport of Berlin
column3: the federal capital of Germany. The airport is named after Otto Lilienthal and was the fourth busiest airport in Germany
column4: with 20.5 million passengers in 2017 and about 22 million in 2018. The airport is a hub for Eurowings as well as a base for EasyJet. It features flights to several European metropolitan and leisure destinations as well as some intercontinental routes. It is situated in Tegel
column5: a section of the northern borough of Reinickendorf
column6: 8 km (5.0 mi) northwest of the city centre of Berlin. Tegel Airport is notable for its hexagonal main terminal building around an open square
column7: which makes walking distances as short as 30 m (98 ft) from the aircraft to the terminal exit.

column1: The airport is due to permanently close with the last flight scheduled for 8 November 2020. Traffic will be transferred gradually in stages to the new Berlin Brandenburg Airport from 31 October 2020. Tegel Nord will still be used for military helicopter flights until 2029.
The area of today's airport originally was part of the Jungfernheide forest
column2: which served as a hunting ground for the Prussian nobility. During the 19th century
column3: it was used as an artillery firing range. Aviation history dates back to the early 20th century
column4: when the Royal Prussian Airship battalion was based there and the area became known as Luftschiffhafen Reinickendorf. In 1906
column5: a hangar was built for testing of Groß-Basenach and Parseval type airships.Soon after the outbreak of World War I
column7: the area was dedicated to military training of aerial reconnaissance crews. Following the war
column8: all aviation industry was removed as a consequence of the Treaty of Versailles
column9: which prohibited Germany from having any armed aircraft. On 27 September 1930

column11: which included German rocket pioneer Wernher von Braun. In 1937
column12: the rocket pioneers left Tegel in favour of the secret Peenemünde army research centre.During World War II
column13: the area served once again as a military training area
column14: mostly for Flak troops. It was destroyed in Allied air raids.

column1: Court Line Aviation was a major British independent airline of the early 1970s that served Berlin Tegel with a series of regular charter flights from its base at London–Luton and Paris Le Bourget Airport between 1970 and 1974 under contract to the students travel company of Berlin's Technical University.

column1: These were the days when liberalisation of the EU/EEA internal air transport market was still in progress and when domestic traffic rights were reserved for each member country's own airlines. The German government therefore insisted that all non-German EU/EEA carriers either withdraw their internal German scheduled services from Berlin or transfer them to majority German-owned subsidiaries by the end of 1992. It also wanted the bulk of all charter flights from Berlin to be operated by German airlines. These measures were squarely aimed at UK carriers with a major presence in the internal German air transport market from Berlin as well as the city's charter market
column2: specifically British Airways and Dan-Air. Lufthansa and other German airlines reportedly lobbied their government to curtail British Airways's and Dan-Air's activities in Berlin
column3: arguing that German airlines enjoyed no equivalent rights in the UK. This resulted in British Airways taking a 49% stake in Friedrichshafen-based German regional airline Delta Air
column4: renaming it Deutsche BA (DBA) and transferring its internal German traffic rights to the new airline. BA also replaced the commuter aircraft DBA had inherited from Delta Air with new Boeing 737-300s. column1: Tegel consists of five terminals. As the airport is small compared to other major airports
column2: these terminals might be regarded as "halls"
column3: "boarding areas"
column4: or “mini-terminals" if they share the same building.

column1: The main building is the original part of the airport. It consists of two parts:
Terminal A is a hexagon-shaped ring concourse with a parking area
column2: taxi stands and bus stops in its middle. It features 14 jet bridges which correspond to 16 respective check-in counters (A00–A15)
column3: with jetways 1 and 14 each serving two check-in counters. There is no transit zone
column4: which means that each gate has its own security clearance checkpoint and exit for arriving passengers. Therefore
column5: direct flight connections without leaving the airside area are not possible. Most major airlines arrive and depart here
column6: especially "prestigious" flights like intercontinental services or flights to the busy European hub airports; for example United Airlines flights to Newark and Lufthansa services to Munich and Frankfurt are handled here. The whole rooftop works as a visitor platform. Terminal A is capable of handling wide-bodied aircraft up to the size of a Boeing 767-400ER or Airbus A330-300 on two positions but with only one jet bridge attached to each.

column1: Terminal B (also called "Nebel-Hall" after German spaceflight pioneer Rudolf Nebel) is a converted former waiting area in a side wing of the main building and features check-in counters B20–B39. There is only one walk-boarding aircraft stand directly serving it. This single stand however can handle widebody aircraft up to the size of the Boeing 777-300ER – currently operated into Tegel by Qatar Airways – and Boeing 747-400.

Terminal C was opened in May 2007 as a temporary solution because all other terminals operated on their maximum capacity. It was largely used by Air Berlin until its demise. It features 26 check-in counters and the gates numbered C38-C51
column2: C60–C67 (Section C2) and C80-C89 (in the newest addition Section C3). From 2008 until August 2009
column3: 5 additional aircraft stands were constructed and the building was expanded by approximately 50% of its original size
column4: in order to handle another 1.5 million passengers per year. The extended terminal now houses a transit zone for connecting passengers which does not exist at any other terminal at Tegel Airport. Due to noise protection treaties
column5: the overall number of aircraft stands at the airport is restricted
column6: thus aircraft stands on the apron (serving Terminals A and D) had to be removed for compensation. Terminal C is able to handle widebody-aircraft like formerly Air Berlin's Airbus A330-200s up to the size of a Boeing 747-400 but features no jet bridges.

column1: Terminal D was opened in 2001 and is a converted car park. It features 22 check-in counters (D70–D91)
column2: with one bus-boarding gate and two walk-boarding gates. Most passengers of airlines operating smaller aircraft (like Embraer 190s for example) are brought to the remote aircraft stands by bus from here. Terminal D is the only part of the airport that remains open all night long. The lower level arrival area is called Terminal E (Gates E16-E18).

column1: Tegel Airport was originally planned to have a second hexagonal terminal like the main building right next to it. The second terminal ring was never built because of Berlin municipal budgetary constraints and the post-reunification decision to replace the former West Berlin airports with the new Berlin Brandenburg Airport.
The following airlines operate regular scheduled and charter flights at Berlin Tegel Airport:

column2: Tegel handled over 60% of all airline passenger traffic in Berlin.

column1: Tegel Airport does not have a direct rail connection
column2: but is served by several bus routes and motorways.

column1: An underground station directly serving the airport had been planned since the 1960s
column2: but it was never built due to the expected closure of Tegel Airport. Note that the Alt-Tegel U-Bahn station and Tegel S-Bahn station do not serve Tegel Airport
column3: but rather the Tegel-quarter of Berlin. Extensions of the tram system from Hauptbahnhof to the airport and the U6 branch from Kurt-Schumacher Platz to the airport are being discussed
column4: but it is unclear whether these extensions will open before the closure of the airport.

column1: The airport has a direct connection to motorway A111 (Exit Flughafen Tegel) which further links it to motorways A10
column2: A110 and A115 (via A110) reaching out in all directions. Taxis and car hire are available at the airport
column3: and Alexanderplatz
column4: in the city center
column5: can be reached within 25 minutes.

column1: The airport is linked by several BVG bus lines
column2: which offer connection to the U-Bahn and S-Bahn
column3: as well as to Regional Express trains and long distance trains:

column1: The TXL express bus runs to Beusselstraße S-Bahn station
column2: Berlin Central station (within 20 minutes). It has frequent departures between 7 am and 10 pm.

column1: The X9 express bus runs to Jakob-Kaiser Platz U-Bahn station (within 5 minutes)
column2: Jungfernheide S-Bahn and Regional Express station
column3: and Zoologischer Garten U-Bahn/S-Bahn/Regional Express station (within 20 minutes).

column1: The 109 bus runs to Jakob-Kaiser Platz U-Bahn station
column2: Charlottenburg S-Bahn and Regional Express station (within 20 minutes)
column3: and Zoologischer Garten U-Bahn/S-Bahn/Regional Express station (within 30 minutes) (runs via Kurfürstendamm).

column1: The 128 bus runs to Kurt-Schumacher-Platz U-Bahn station (within 10 minutes) and Osloer Straße U-Bahn station (within 25 minutes).Tegel Airport is in the Verkehrsverbund Berlin-Brandenburg's Berlin B fare zone. There is no additional fare for BVG services to and from the airport.
There are no recorded fatal accidents involving commercial airline operations at Berlin Tegel itself. However
column2: two commercial flights
column3: one of which was due to arrive at Tegel Airport and the other of which had departed the airport
column4: were involved in fatal accidents. These accidents are listed below:

column2: Clipper München
column3: a Pan Am Boeing 727–21 (registration N317PA) operating the return leg of the airline's daily cargo flight to Berlin from Frankfurt Rhein-Main Airport (flight number PA 708) was due to land that night at Tegel Airport
column4: rather than Tempelhof
column5: due to runway resurfacing work taking place at that time at the latter. Berlin Control had cleared flight 708 for an Instrument Landing System (ILS) approach to Tegel Airport's runway 08
column6: soon after the crew had begun its descent from Flight Level (FL) 090 to FL 030 before entering the southwest air corridor over East Germany on the last stretch of its journey to Berlin. The aircraft impacted the ground near Dallgow
column8: almost immediately after the crew had acknowledged further instructions received from Berlin Control
column9: just 10 mi (16 km) from Tegel Airport. All three crew members lost their lives in this accident. Visibility was poor
column10: and it was snowing at the time of the accident. Following the accident
column11: the Soviet military authorities in East Germany returned only half of the aircraft's wreckage to their US counterparts in West Berlin. This excluded vital parts
column12: such as the flight data recorder (FDR)
column13: the cockpit voice recorder (CVR) as well as the plane's flight control systems
column14: its navigation and communication equipment. The subsequent National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) investigation report concluded that the aircraft's descent below its altitude clearance limit was the accident's probable cause. However
column15: the NTSB was unable to establish the factors that had caused the crew to descend below its cleared minimum altitude.The following notable
column16: non-fatal incidents involving airline operations occurred at Tegel. These include commercial flights that were about to depart or had actually departed/arrived as well as unscheduled stopovers:

column2: Berlin Tegel was the destination of several aircraft hijackings involving LOT Polish Airlines domestic flights within Poland. The hijackings were a means of forcing the authorities in communist Poland to let the hijackers emigrate from the Eastern Bloc. Once the aircraft had landed at Tegel
column3: the French military authorities in charge of the airport during the Cold War era let the hijackers and anyone else who did not wish to return to Poland disembark and claim political asylum in West Berlin. The aircraft
column4: its crew and those passengers who did not want to disembark were subsequently returned to Poland.

column1: Upon completing the repair and run-up of the faulty engine that had caused a rejected takeoff due to an engine oil warning at Berlin Tegel during the late 1980s
column2: a Dan-Air Boeing 727-200 Adv collided with a jetway at the airport's terminal building while maintenance engineers taxied the aircraft back to its stand. This badly injured the ground crew member manning the jetway and ruptured the fully refuelled aircraft's centre wing tank at the left wing root. As a result
column3: a large quantity of jet fuel spilled onto the tarmac. The maintenance engineers' failure to pressurise the aircraft's hydraulics had resulted in a complete loss of hydraulic pressure just before reaching the stand
column4: making it impossible to steer the aircraft and rendering the brakes ineffective.

column2: Austrian Airlines flight 104
column3: a McDonnell Douglas MD-87 en route to Vienna International Airport
column4: was hijacked shortly after takeoff from Tegel Airport by a Bosnian male carrying a knife (which was small enough to be allowed on board under then valid safety regulations). The pilots were forced to return to Berlin
column5: where the perpetrator was overpowered by German police forces.

column2: an Air France Boeing 737-500 skidded off the runway while landing at Berlin Tegel due to a suspected brake defect. There were no injuries.There were also two Cold war era incidents relating to an American and a British airliner that had departed Tegel on international non-scheduled passenger services. Both of these occurred in Bulgarian airspace. The former was a charter flight carrying German holidaymakers to the Bulgarian Black Sea coast
column3: the latter a migrant charter en route to Turkey:

column2: a Modern Air CV-990A with 45 passengers on board en route from Berlin Tegel to Bulgaria was unexpectedly denied permission to enter Bulgarian airspace
column3: as a result of a new policy adopted by that country's then communist government to deny any aircraft whose flight had originated or was going to terminate at a West Berlin airport the right to take off and land at any of its airports. This resulted in the aircraft having to turn back to Berlin
column4: where it landed safely at the city's Tegel Airport.

column2: a Dan-Air Comet carrying Turkish migrant workers from Berlin Tegel to Istanbul was "escorted" by Bulgarian fighter planes into Sofia. The crew flying the aircraft was attempting to take the shortest route to Istanbul when leaving Yugoslav airspace by entering Bulgarian airspace
column3: instead of taking the longer route through Greek airspace. They were not aware of the then communist government of Bulgaria's decision not to let any aircraft enter its airspace whose flight had originated or was going to terminate at a West Berlin airport
column4: without stopping en route at another airport outside West Berlin. The aircraft landed safely at Sofia. It was released along with its crew and passengers when the flight's commander paid with the company's credit card the fine the Bulgarian authorities had imposed for violating their country's airspace.

column2: an aviator of whom the airport is named
